text: The drunk’s footsteps drew closer, each one making the glasses on the table tremble. The air was thick with the smell of alcohol.
I didn’t back away—just slowly placed my hand on the hilt of my short sword, fingers tightening slightly.
“You’d better stop right there.”
The drunk paused for a moment, his lip twitching. He clearly didn’t take me seriously, and stepped forward again.
A flash of steel—my sword was already drawn. The cold edge grazed his throat, leaving a pale, shallow line on his skin.
His breath caught. He froze completely, not daring even to move his eyes.
“Move another inch, and I’ll call the town guard.”
The drunk swallowed hard, his throat trembling slightly under the blade.
“Y-you’re not serious… are you?”
I didn’t answer. The sword inched closer, its cold light reflected on his face, freezing the sweat upon it.
Only the crackle of the fire and his ragged breathing filled the silence.
Alicia stood nearby, watching calmly, a faint glint of approval in her eyes.
“Stand down.”
The drunk staggered backward, nearly tripping over himself as he stumbled out the door into the snow.
With a heavy bang, the door slammed shut behind him. The fire flickered once.
I sheathed my short sword. In the firelight, the blade gleamed faintly—like a frozen streak of lightning.
“Well done.”
“I just reacted quickly, that’s all.”
She looked at me for a moment, as if to say something, then gave a faint, unreadable smile.
“Don’t rely on luck.”
She turned, glancing over the overturned tables and the spilled liquor on the floor.
“Clean up. I’ll give you a hand.”
Her voice was still calm, but softer than before.
“All right.”
I set the sword aside and walked back to the counter. The fire crackled to life again, and the chill in the air slowly faded away.
